bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to J.E.S. Thorpe, September 13, 1916

div1.p: Le Prince discusses the treatment of a lake shore, in North Carolina, in order to reduce the number of anopheles mosquitos.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to J.E.S. Thorpe, September 13, 1916
div1.opener:
lamp. Waters
Baden
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
U.S. Public Health Service,
U.S. Marine Hospital,
New Orleans, La.
Fort Lawn, S. C.
Sept. 13, 1916
Please return Badin
Dear Mr. Thorpe:
div1.p:
You requested me to write you regarding such measures as I
thought might be of assistance in preventing the production of
anopheles and spread of malaria in the vicinity of the lake at
Badin N. C.

The surveys made during July and August 1916 showed the
presence of adult anopheles in houses in the area to be flooded
as well as in houses a mile distant. The flooding will eradicate
the productive areas now in the basin, but we expect a much larger
number of anopheles to be produced by the lake next summer and
afterwards.

It is advisable to consider the upper half of all bights
as being the most probable and important sources of the mosquitoes
next summer and particular attention should be given to them when
within 1-1/4 miles of occupied residences. Their shore lines between
high and low water lines should be well cleared, so that no tall
grass, weeds, brush, brambles, etc., or other obstructions, will
collect floatage or act as hiding places or protection for mosquito
lavae. The cleaner or closer it be cut the better.

In the spring, about April or May, the debris that has
collected in the bights should be all removed. There is
no particular reason for close clearing, similar to that mentioned
above, along the main shore line of the lake where strong wave action
will occur, but wherever the wave action is limited and debris and
other protection, such as tall clumps of grass, brembles, tall
weeds, etc., remain anopheles may develop unless top feeding minnows
are very numerous in all parts of the lake. Incidentally these
minnows may concentrate in the arm of the lake that is not cleared
and be scarce in other parts. They know where food is most plentiful.

Mr. Marshall asked me regarding leasing of houses within
flight range of the lake. It would be fair to the tenant as well as
the lessor to include a clause in the lease relieving the lessor from
all responsibility regarding danger to health or illness that may
occur. It will prevent future misunderstanding.

(1) The upper half of all bights be cleared of all vegetation
close to the ground from above the high water line to below the low
water line, where such areas are within 11/4 miles of habitations.

(2) That floating debris abd floatage be not left in bights or
places having but little wave action (after the breeding season
begins). Wherever debris collects on the water surface anopheles
may be expected to propagate unless prevented by fish or wave action.
The more prolific the breeding the greater will be the flight range
of the malaria conveying mosquito.

(3) More care should be given to close cutting of stumps.
The trees and saplings have been cut high and not close to the ground
as was recommended. This will probably interfere with the stranding
of debris and floatage and in some places will assist in collecting
it and in the increased production of anopheles.

(4) The following sections of the February survey are considered
important.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, (Signed) J. A. Le Prince COPY
